awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Aerosol-Assisted Water-Vapor Air Conditioner
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project is aimed at utilizing aerosol technology to solve heat transfer problems in small-scale air conditioning systems, thus enabling the use of water as a refrigerant in small-scale units for domestic and automobile applications. A water-based air conditioning system must operate under vacuum, thus raising concerns of air leaking into the system. Also, the presence of water in a system is associated with the risk of corrosion. Further, the proposed system requires design and development of a special compressor. These issues are addressed in this project and viable solutions are proposed. Advancements in the pertinent technologies are now enabling realization of water-based air conditioning systems. This project underlines the importance of revisiting the conventional technologies with the new tools developed for the advanced technologies. The anticipated outcome of this Phase I project is a fully functional lab prototype of a water-based air conditioning system with a capacity of 0.25 ton. A successful Phase I project will enable development of field prototypes for domestic and automobile applications in the Phase II project.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project encompasses all air conditioning applications; in particular, the markets of newly built homes and new automobiles. The domestic US market for these two businesses is $5B/year, with potentially 10 times this market on a worldwide basis. Annual revenue expectations exceed $100 million. Besides offering a significant commercial opportunity, the proposed product will have a positive impact on the environment by reducing the use of existing refrigerants that have a high global warming potential, when released into the atmosphere. Production of the existing refrigerants involves multiple steps starting with extraction of chemicals like methane and sodium chloride from the natural environment. Various steps in production of the conventional refrigerants are often energy-intensive and produce hazardous waste. On the other hand, water is abundantly available in the anticipated global marketplace and its purification is a relatively straightforward process. Hence, the proposed approach will enable a new, substantial and sustainable technology.

por.por_cntn:
Innovation

MSP Corporation is developing a novel air conditioning system that utilizes water as the refrigerant. As shown in the system layout image, refrigerant (water) evaporates to provide cooling and thus removes heat from the chilled water which is circulated to the space to be cooled. Water vapors are taken up by the adsorbent, which is represented by Zeolite Column 1 in the diagram. Vapor flow through Zeolite Column 1 is assisted with a compressor. The compressor handles only a small fraction of the vapor, as most of the vapor is adsorbed in the zeolite column before reaching the compressor inlet. Heat of adsorption from Zeolite Column 1 is removed by cooling water. While Zeolite Column 1 adsorbs water and approaches saturation, Zeolite Column 2 is regenerated with heat from a hot fluid (this can be hot water or some other heat transfer fluid), which is the main source of energy for this air conditioning system. Heat used in this system may be waste heat from an industrial process, solar heat or waste heat from the exhaust of an engine. Heat drives water out of the adsorbent in Zeolite Column 2 in the form of vapors. These vapors, together with the vapors from the compressor outlet, are cooled and condensed in the condenser and finally returned to the evaporator through an expansion valve, which reduces the pressure and cools the liquid. When a zeolite column saturates with adsorbed water, its opening to the evaporator is closed. Evaporator is then opened to a freshly regenerated adsorbent column and the other adsorbent column is subsequently regenerated with the hot fluid.

In Phase I project, we have experimentally validated the concept of the device. As shown in the second image, our prototype is capable of forming ice without using any harmful refrigerants. Further, we have experimentally determined the key design parameters, such as zeolite regeneration time and weight of zeolite needed per ton of the cooling effect. We have completed the preliminary design of a unit with 12-ton cooling capacity that will be built to operate with waste heat from a standalone power generator with an electrical capacity of 300 kW. The combined unit will provide electricity, heating and cooling to a commercial building or a small manufacturing facility.

Intellectual Merit

Our design of the water-based air conditioning system is novel and not reported before. MSP is seeking a patent on this technology, as it will make use of water in air conditioning systems viable for a variety of applications (Naqwi, A., B.Y.H. Liu and T. Dinh, “Air Conditioning System with Vapor Bypassing,” Patent pending). MSP and partners are currently pursing combined electricity, heating and cooling generation. Future applications would include residential and automotive cooling using solar and engine waste heat.

Broader Impact

This project is aimed at developing air conditioners that will use water as the refrigerant. Currently, Refrigerant-134a is widely used as it has mitigated the problem of ozone layer depletion caused by the earlier refrigerants. However, it is a highly potent greenhouse gas and has a 20-year Global Warming Potential of about 4000 relative to carbon dioxide, i.e. release of 1 kg of Refrigerant-134a would cause about as much global warming as 4 tons of carbon dioxide. Further, production of Refrigerant-134a is an energy-intensive process. Use of low-pressure water as a working fluid for refrigeration is attractive due to its potential for making refrigeration a safe, sustainable and environmentally-friendly technology. Water-based air conditioning is also attractive because it utilizes waste heat or solar heat as the source of energy and minimizes electricity consumption.
